feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Business Technology Platform
feed.subtitle: SAP Business Technology Platform Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: SAP Joule Introduction and its applications in SAP FICO
entry.content:
What Is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is SAP‚Äôs AI copilot embedded across its cloud applications. It offers four interaction types‚ÄîTransactional, Navigational, Informational, and Analytical‚Äîthat let users perform business tasks via natural language within SAP environments. It understands user context, roles, permissions, and remains secure by design. It can also ground responses in your own business documents.

 How SAP Joule works in Public vs. Private Cloud is one of the most important considerations for finance teams (especially in FICO) deciding on adoption.

Here‚Äôs a structured view:

üîπ SAP Joule in Public vs. Private Cloud

  1. Deployment & Integration
  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
    • Joule is natively embedded and updated by SAP automatically.
    • Integration with SAP FICO apps (GL, AP, AR, Asset Accounting, Controlling) is out of the box.
    • No additional installation required - users just activate and configure.
  • Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)
    • Joule can be enabled, but may require additional setup and integration.
    • Some Joule features might lag behind public cloud, because public gets innovations first.
    • Still integrates with FICO, but might require extra configuration & tenant connections to SAP BTP.
  1. Feature Availability
  • Public Cloud
    • Joule supports all 4 interaction types (Transactional, Navigational, Informational, Analytical) directly in Fiori apps.
    • Example in FICO: ‚ÄúPost vendor invoice‚Äù ‚Üí transaction executes directly.
    • Faster delivery of Joule Agents and Joule Studio.
  • Private Cloud
    • Informational & Analytical features available early (queries, reports, insights).
    • Transactional flows may require enablement through custom skills/agents.
    • Joule Studio can still be connected via SAP BTP, but adoption speed depends on customer‚Äôs upgrade cycle.
  1. Customization & Extensibility
  • Public Cloud
    • Limited custom coding‚Äîextensions must go through SAP BTP side-by-side development.
    • Joule skills/agents are mostly standardized.
    • Great if you want speed & standardization.
  • Private Cloud
    • More flexibility: you can create custom FICO processes, reports, and Joule agents.
    • Easier to integrate with on-prem or legacy systems.
    • Suited for companies with complex finance processes.
  1. Data Security & Residency
  • Public Cloud
    • Data is hosted on SAP-managed hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP, SAP DCs).
    • Joule queries financial data via secure APIs; customers rely on SAP‚Äôs compliance.
  • Private Cloud
    • You control hosting, location, and more of the security stack.
    • Some finance-heavy industries (banking, defense, public sector) may prefer this for regulatory reasons.
  1. Upgrade & Innovation
  • Public Cloud
    • Quarterly upgrades ‚Üí Joule features arrive first and fastest.
    • Example: New Joule Agents for FICO tasks (like dispute resolution) appear immediately.
  • Private Cloud
    • Annual upgrades (with optional Feature Packs).
    • Joule features arrive later‚Äîinnovation follows public cloud by a few cycles.

üìä Comparison Table

Aspect

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Availability

Native, out-of-the-box

Needs setup, later adoption

Updates

Quarterly, fastest innovations

Annual/controlled upgrades

Customization

Limited, BTP-based

Flexible, deep customizations

Security

SAP-managed hyperscalers

Customer-controlled

FICO Use Cases

Immediate transactional & analytical support

Strong for complex, regulated finance scenarios

Joule Studio

Fully available

Available via BTP, more flexible

‚úÖ Which is Better for FICO?

  • Public Cloud ‚Üí Best if you want rapid innovation, standard finance processes, faster AI adoption.
  • Private Cloud ‚Üí Best if you need deep customization, strict compliance, hybrid IT integration.

 SAP Joule version requirements for S/4HANA Cloud editions (Public and Private):

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Joule arrived as part of the Public Cloud starting around Q3 2024, and is embedded in all releases thereafter, including 2408 (August 2024) and onward.
  • While Joule is built into these releases, you still need proper entitlement and authorization to use it; this may require activation via your SAP admin or account executive.
  • There are setup guides available detailing how to activate Joule once entitlement is granted.

In Summary:

If your system is on Public Cloud release 2408 (Aug 2024) or later, Joule is already supported‚Äîassuming you've got the right access and permissions.

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • Joule is available in the Private Cloud as well, but requires setup and configuration. It's not automatically active‚Äîyou must enable it via SAP BTP and Joule Studio.
  • Technical prerequisites include ensuring the UI5 version in your system meets or exceeds the minimum required for Joule integration. The specific UI5 version will depend on your release; you can consult SAP documentation for exact details.

In Summary:

Private Cloud systems can support Joule‚Äîbut you must set it up, ensure the UI5 stack is compatible, and configure the feature via BTP.

  1. SAP S/4HANA On-Premise (Classic)
  • Joule is not supported on on-premise S/4HANA. SAP has confirmed it's not on the current roadmap for classic on-premise systems.
  • There‚Äôs a planned strategy‚Äîpossibly coming Q1 2025‚Äîto enable Joule via SAP Build Work Zone, BTP, and Joule Studio even for on-prem systems. But as of now, Joule remains unavailable on-prem and unsupported.

High-Level Overview

Edition

Supported from (release)

Requirements

Public Cloud

2408 (Aug 2024) onward

Needs entitlement/authorization & activation

Private Cloud

Post-2024 releases

Requires UI5 prerequisites + BTP/Joule Studio setup

On-Premise (classic)

Not supported (as of now)

No Joule availability; roadmap may include future BTP-based solution

Summary:

  • Public Cloud: Joule is supported starting with 2408 onward‚Äîactivate it via entitlement.
  • Private Cloud: Joule is available but not automatic‚Äîrequires UI compliance + setup via BTP.
  • On-Premise: Joule is not supported yet; no built-in version availability.

Here‚Äôs how SAP Joule, SAP‚Äôs generative AI assistant, can be applied specifically within the SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling) domain:

SAP Joule Application in FICO

  1. Transactional Interactions

Joule allows users to perform CRUD operations and manage financial documents via natural language‚Äîimagine asking:

  • ‚ÄúPost a vendor invoice of $5,000 to account X with due date Y.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúShow me the status of PO invoice 10234.‚Äù
    While SAP hasn't yet released out-of-the-box FICO conversational flows, Joule‚Äôs transactional model supports this kind of interaction across cloud applications.
  1. Navigational Interactions

Instead of navigating through menus to reach Fiori apps like ‚ÄúDisplay GL Account Balances,‚Äù you could simply ask:

  • ‚ÄúWhere can I review G/L balances?‚Äù
    Joule will direct you to the relevant screen.
  1. Informational Interactions

Straight answers instead of digging through help docs. You can ask:

  • ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the difference between cost center and profit center accounting?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúExplain account determination for automatic postings.‚Äù
    Joule will deliver concise explanations, referencing SAP documentation or your own policy documents.
  1. Analytical Interactions

Joule bridges your natural-language queries to data analytics:

  • ‚ÄúShow me quarterly expense trends per cost center.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?‚Äù
    It returns charts, metrics, or dashboards‚Äîleveraging SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Advanced: Joule Agents & Studio

Joule Agents

SAP has introduced AI agents‚Äîautonomous actors capable of executing complex, multi-step workflows across business functions. In FICO, custom agents could:

  • Automate dispute resolution: Collaborate across finance and service teams to validate discrepancies and propose corrections.
  • Cash collection workflows: Analyze overdue invoices, coordinate with collections, and initiate follow-ups.
    These agents are part of SAP‚Äôs cross-functional automation strategy.

Joule Studio (within SAP Build)

No-code/low-code tool to create custom skills or agents tailored for your FICO needs:

  • Build a skill to automatically generate internal financial reports, or trigger approval workflows.
  • Automate vendor reconciliation or recurring postings by designing tailored AI agents.
    These skills and agents integrate across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Summary Table

Joule Capability

FICO Use Case Example

Transactional

Post invoices, check payment status via natural language

Navigational

Ask ‚ÄúWhere to view Cost Center Reports?‚Äù

Informational

Clarify financial terms or posting rules

Analytical

Generate trends and KPI charts using SAC

Agents & Studio

Automate dispute resolution, cash collection, approvals

Key Benefits in FICO

  • Boost Productivity: Save time by speaking instead of clicking through screens.
  • Reduce Errors: Leverage conversational clarity and auto-generated documents.
  • Improve Insights: Conduct data reviews and root cause analysis through simple dialogue.
  • Automate Complex Workflows: Agents handle multi-step tasks such as reconciliations or approvals automatically.

Real-World Usage Context -- Caveats

While SAP is rapidly developing Joule‚Äôs capabilities, many implementations remain in pilot or PoC stages. Users in forums report limited early usage, primarily for basic navigation or queries.

 

Here are concrete FICO scenarios where you could pilot SAP Joule and even extend it with Joule Agents / Studio:

üîπ Pilot Scenarios in SAP FICO

  1. Invoice & Payment Handling
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúPost an invoice for vendor ABC with $12,000 due in 30 days.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Creates the posting, validates tax code, and confirms with you.
  • Extension with Agent: Automate follow-up‚Äîif payment not cleared by due date, Joule Agent triggers a reminder email or escalates.
  1. Month-End Close Assistant
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúWhat are the pending tasks for month-end close?‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Lists open items (accruals, GR/IR clearing, reconciliations).
  • Extension with Agent: Automate recurring accrual postings and send alerts to approvers who are late in providing confirmations.
  1. Financial Analysis & Insights
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúShow me expense trend per cost center for last 6 months.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Returns a chart (via SAC integration).
  • Extension with Agent: Forecast next quarter‚Äôs expenses and flag cost centers that may exceed budgets.
  1. Audit & Compliance Checks
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúList journal entries above $50,000 in the last quarter without approvals.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Generates a filtered list.
  • Extension with Agent: Create an automated internal audit agent that periodically checks for compliance exceptions and notifies controllers.
  1. Treasury & Cash Management
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúWhat is today‚Äôs cash position?‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Summarizes bank balances, incoming/outgoing payments.
  • Extension with Agent: Auto-generate a daily treasury dashboard at 9 AM and send to CFO.
  1. Dispute & Collections Management
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúShow me customers with invoices overdue > 60 days.‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Lists overdue accounts.
  • Extension with Agent: An AI agent sends personalized payment reminders and schedules calls with collections staff.
  1. Budget vs. Actual Control
  • Ask Joule:
    ‚ÄúWhich cost centers exceeded budget last quarter?‚Äù
  • Joule Action: Shows variances with drill-down.
  • Extension with Agent: Automatically notify budget owners when variances exceed a threshold (say 10%).

üîπ How to Design in Joule Studio

In Joule Studio (within SAP Build) you can:

  1. Create a Skill ‚Üí ‚ÄúGenerate quarterly P&L by company code and send PDF to finance team.‚Äù
  2. Create an Agent ‚Üí ‚ÄúMonitor overdue vendor payments and auto-initiate dunning.‚Äù
  3. Connect Non-SAP Apps ‚Üí e.g., send approvals via MS Teams or Slack.

üëâ This way, Joule moves from a copilot (answering queries) to a colleague (executing finance tasks for you).

 

Deep Dive on one of the real-world example: Vendor Invoice Posting with SAP Joule in Public vs Private Cloud.

üßæ Example: Vendor Invoice Posting with Joule

üîπ Scenario

A finance user wants to post a vendor invoice for Vendor 300012, amount $12,000, due in 30 days.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    üëâ ‚ÄúPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.‚Äù
  • Joule Process:
    1. Understands the intent (‚ÄúCreate Vendor Invoice‚Äù).
    2. Pulls relevant master data (Vendor 300012 details, tax code, payment terms).
    3. Pre-fills the invoice screen in Fiori.
    4. User confirms ‚Üí Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Public Cloud:
    • Joule can immediately display the document number and due date schedule.
    • If connected to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Joule can also show how this impacts cash outflow forecast.
    • Minimal setup ‚Üí available out-of-the-box.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Private Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition)

  • User says to Joule:
    üëâ ‚ÄúPost a vendor invoice of $12,000 for Vendor 300012, due in 30 days.‚Äù
  • Joule Process:
    1. Joule recognizes intent, but instead of direct posting, it may:
      • Provide navigation ‚Üí ‚ÄúOpen FB60 (Vendor Invoice Entry)‚Äù or ‚ÄúFiori App: Create Supplier Invoice.‚Äù
      • Pre-fill metadata only if integrated with custom Joule Skill via Joule Studio.
    2. User manually confirms or adjusts in the classic posting screen (e.g., FB60 / MIRO).
    3. Invoice is posted.
  • Extras in Private Cloud:
    • You can customize Joule Agent (via Joule Studio + BTP) to enforce company-specific validations (e.g., block invoices >$10,000 without 2 approvals).
    • Joule can connect to legacy non-SAP apps (like OCR invoice scanners or in-house workflow systems).
    • Requires more setup & governance compared to Public Cloud.

üìä Side-by-Side Comparison

Step

Public Cloud

Private Cloud

Activation

Native, plug-and-play

Needs setup & integration

Invoice Posting

Joule executes directly in Fiori app

Joule suggests navigation, may require custom agent for automation

Data Validation

Standard rules auto-applied

Flexible, can embed custom compliance rules

User Effort

Minimal (voice/text ‚Üí posted)

Moderate (confirmation in screen, extra steps if no custom agent)

Analytics

Immediate cash flow impact via SAC

Possible, but may need manual SAC integration

Customization

Limited (SAP-standard process)

Flexible (custom workflows, approvals, legacy integration)

‚úÖ Takeaway:

  • In Public Cloud, Joule = speed + simplicity ‚Üí perfect for companies with standard finance processes.
  • In Private Cloud, Joule = control + flexibility ‚Üí better if you need extra compliance steps, custom posting logic, or hybrid integration.

Joule SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics SAP S/4HANA Finance SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Service SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Sales

entry.title: Approuter: Error getting client_credentials
entry.content:
We operate a multi-tenant solution on SAP BTP and rely on the @sap/approuter package as our initial entry-point which connects to the portal service and a number of Fiori Elements HTML5 applications hosted using html5-apps-repo services. This is a setup we have used for many years without any issue.

We recently bumped the version of the approuter package from 16.4.x to the 20.6.1 and after deploying this change in our production environment, we started getting reports of intermittent issues loading HTML5 apps:

I inspected the approuter logs and found that we had a number of errors matching this format:

Error getting client_credentials token for html5-apps-repo-rt from subaccount <tenant-subdomain>: 
HTTP response from https://<tenant-subdomain>.authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token was 401: 
{"error":"invalid_client","error_description":"Bad credentials"}.

 I referred back to the CHANGELOG.md for the approuter package and noticed that there had recently been some changes related to client credentials. I also noticed that a new version of the package was available (20.7.0) included a fix related to client_credentials and saas which I thought might address the issue we were experiencing:

- Read grant_type and saas.registry.enabled from service credentials in client_credentials token flow

We applied this update but are still experiencing the same behavior. 

I recognize that jumping multiple major versions (16->20) of a package has the potential for unexpected outcomes but the CHANGELOG.md did not have any indications that changes between any of these versions introduced major breaking changes. 

If anyone can provide any insights on how to proceed, it would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Business Application Studio Cannot See BTP Destinations (Platform Issue)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am facing a persistent issue where my Business Application Studio dev space is unable to see a BTP destination I've configured. The destination itself is set up correctly and the connection to my on-premise system is working perfectly, but it does not appear in the Fiori generator.

Environment:

  • BTP Environment: Trial Account

  • Region: US East (VA) - AWS

  • BAS Dev Space Type: SAP Fiori

Summary of the situation:

  1. I have successfully installed and configured the SAP Cloud Connector.

  2. I have created a destination in my BTP subaccount that connects to my on-premise SAP system. This destination has the required properties: HTML5.DynamicDestination = true and WebIDEUsage = odata_gen.

  3. Crucially, when I click the "Check Connection" button for this destination in the BTP Cockpit, the check is successful and returns a "200 OK - Backend is reachable" message. This confirms the entire end-to-end connection is working correctly.

  4. However, when I go into a Business Application Studio dev space and use the SAP Fiori generator, this destination does not appear in the "System" dropdown list.

  5. I have tried restarting the dev space, which did not solve the issue. I then deleted the dev space and created a brand new "SAP Fiori" dev space, and the destination is still not visible.

  6. When I run the diagnostic command npx fiori-tools destination in the terminal of the new dev space, I receive a DNS error:

    npm ERR! code ENOTFOUND
npm ERR! syscall getaddrinfo
npm ERR! errno ENOTFOUND
npm ERR! request to https://.../_.../destinations failed, reason: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND ...

This ENOTFOUND error in a brand new dev space, combined with the successful connection check in the cockpit, strongly suggests a platform-level DNS or networking issue within the BAS environment for my trial account.

Could you please advise if this is a known issue or what the next steps should be? I believe I have exhausted all possible configuration and troubleshooting steps.

Thank you for your help.

entry.title: Deployed CAP+Fiori App is running, but UI gives 404 on metadata call and is not visible in Work Zone
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm developing a full-stack application in SAP Business Application Studio and I'm facing a final issue after a seemingly successful deployment to Cloud Foundry.

My Project Setup:

  • Backend: SAP CAP with Node.js

  • Database: SAP HANA Cloud, using synonyms to access tables from another container.

  • Frontend: SAP Fiori Elements (List Report Object Page template).

  • Security: Using a standard XSUAA service.

  • Deployment Target: The final goal is to integrate the app into our SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.

The Problem / Observed Behavior: The deployment to Cloud Foundry using cf deploy completes 100% successfully. In the CF space, I can see that my applications (-srv, -ui) are in the "Started" state, and the -db-deployer is "Stopped", which is the expected behavior.

The issue is that the application is unreachable and invisible to end-users:

  1. When I access the direct URL of the CAP backend service (...-srv.cfapps...), I correctly see the CAP welcome page listing my service endpoint at /odata/v4/catalog. This confirms the backend is alive and serving the correct path.

  2. However, when I access the main UI application URL (...-ui.cfapps...), the page title loads, but the rest of the page is blank.

  3. Checking the browser's developer console, I see a 404 (Not Found) error when the application tries to fetch the service metadata. The failing request is: GET .../odata/v4/catalog/$metadata.

  4. Consequently, the application does not appear in the Content Explorer of the SAP Build Work Zone after refreshing the "HTML5 Apps" content provider.

My Question: What could be the reason for the 404 Not Found error during the metadata call from the UI, given that the deployment is successful and the backend service is confirmed to be running and serving the correct path? It seems there is a routing or communication issue between the AppRouter (-ui app) and the CAP service (-srv app) that I am unable to diagnose further.

Relevant Configuration Files attached

entry.title: Is there any reason to purchase SAP BTP when using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?
entry.content:
Hello,
I have some questions about the Developer Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition).

  1.  I would like to create a RAP application by connecting to SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition) via ADT.
        Is it possible to create custom tables starting with prefix Z_?

       According to the following tutorial, it seems possible, but I have not been able to find an official reference:
       > https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-s4hanacloud-procurement-purchasereq-shop..html

   2. If creating custom tables is possible, wouldn‚Äôt using the ABAP Environment service instance on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) for side-by-side extensibility be considered an overdose?
      In other words, if a customer is already adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition), is there a real necessity to also introduce SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform)?

I would greatly appreciate any clarification or reference documentation you could share.
Thank you very much in advance for your support and guidance.

Best regards,

entry.title: honecomb mta-scan error: path /workspace/source-our-app/our-app/target/our-app-1.0.0.jar/ not exists
entry.content:
Hello Team,
We have CodeQL(2.21.4) tool configured in github->Repo->Security->Code Scanning.

In honeycomb, we have MTA-SCAN pipeline setup and we can run the scan from honeycomb.

Earlier the scan was running fine but recently its failing.

Its forming below command:
codeql database create /workspace/source-our-app/our-app/target/our-app-1.0.0.jar/codeqldb --source-root /workspace/source-our-app/our-app/target/our-app-1.0.0.jar --threads=0 --overwrite --language=java-kotlin --command='mvn package -DskipTests=true'

and this command failing with error:
Path /workspace/source-our-app/our-app/target/our-app-1.0.0.jar does not exists.

CodeQL creates workspace path in previous step as : /workspace/source-our-app

and then it is appending our-app/target/our-app-1.0.0.jar in next step in create command.

This our-app/target/our-app-1.0.0.jar path is configured in mta.yml.

If we modify mta.yml to change path to '.' mta-scan works but deployment to btp will fail.

So any workaround or fix for this issue.

How can we fix path for create command without modifying path in mta.yml.

Any other settings required in github in our repo ?

entry.title: How to Handle Cross-Global Account Subscriptions and Customer-Managed HANA in CAP SaaS?
entry.content:
A SaaS solution built using SAP CAP (Node.js) with MTX-enabled multitenancy is currently running in production with several subscribed tenants (subaccounts under the same global account).

The solution is deployed as an MTA in a provider subaccount, while each customer has a dedicated subscriber subaccount to consume the application.

HANA setup

At the moment, I use a shared HANA Cloud database. The MTX sidecar creates a Service Manager HDI container for each tenant, and together with the CDS framework, it handles multitenancy properly.

Customer concern

One customer raised data privacy concerns, since the solution connects to their S/4HANA system (via Cloud Connector) and stores data in our HANA Cloud.

My questions

Part 1: Is it possible for a customer to subscribe to the SaaS application from a subaccount in a different global account (not the same global account as the provider subaccount)? I am particularly thinking about potential XSUAA-related challenges here.

Part 2: Is it possible to support a ‚Äúbring your own HANA‚Äù (BYO HANA) model, where the CDS framework would connect to a customer-managed HANA instance instead of the shared one?

I understand this may be a stretch given the current state of CAP applications, but I‚Äôd appreciate any insights into what SAP offers in terms of architectural possibilities and limitations in this area.

Thank you !

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite unavailable in marketplace after adding it in entitlements in KSA-sa30 region
CAP - How to Update Association of Remote Entity without Duplicating Entries in Local DB ?
entry.content:
Dear Reader, 

I have a question about how to deal with remote associations when updating their values from my local CAP application.

Imagine having a schema like this:

entity Products : cuid {
    name  : String;
    price : Integer;
    order : Association to Orders;
    /*
    totalQuantiy : type of order.TotalQuantity;
    startDate    : type of order.MfgOrderPlannedStartDate;
    endDate      : type of order.MfgOrderPlannedEndDate;
    */
}

entity Orders                      as
    projection on API_PRODUCTION_ORDER_2_SRV {
        key ManufacturingOrder,
            TotalQuantity,
            MfgOrderPlannedStartDate,
            MfgOrderPlannedEndDate,
    }

My local CAP application has a Fiori-Eelements frontend and displays all the fields of "Products" in an object page and I dynamically add associated fields to "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" from remote entity "Orders". So when I am reading my "Products" I expand the read to the remote entity with my custom handler, everything is fine. 

But what if I want to update certain elements, like "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" from the remote entity?
My Entity "Products" is draft enabled, but changes in the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" of the association are not triggering any "PUSH" or "UPDATE" event in the backend. 

The problem is, I don't want to persistently add the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" to the entity "Products", that is why I added them in /* */.
I tried making them virtual or computed fields, but then they are also read-only for the Fiori frontend and no event is triggered when changing them. New values are also not delivered to the backend on "save" button in the frontend. 

So the question for me remains, is it only possible to send draft values from the frontend to the backend on persistently saved elements ?
or is there another way I am missing, to somehow allow me to change the values in the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" and receive the new values in the backend, so I can update the remote entity ?

I hope i explained the problem somehow understandable, otherwise feel free to tell me so I can update üôÇ 

thanks for your time, greetings

David

If the problem persists, please post a question to SAP Community.** Best Regards, Jhansi

entry.title: Delta Sync Issue in SSAM 2505 with Basic Authentication
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are setting up a new development application using SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) 2505 with Basic Authentication. During testing, we noticed that delta sync is not working consistently.

Some mobile users are receiving the latest backend changes through delta sync, while others are not. This is causing data mismatches across devices.

Has anyone faced similar issues with delta sync when using Basic Authentication? Any suggestions or insights would be helpful.

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: How to use bdwreferencerequest_in inside a SAP Integration suite iflow for POST operation
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a requirement to create a billing document based on input SalesOrderID. This has to be done inside AP Integration suite (BTP).I looked through various options including oData v4 which does not allows this:

        "message": "Creating operations are disabled for entity '$SRVD_A2X#API_BILLINGDOCUMENT~A_BILLINGDOCUMENT_2'",

 So I narrowed down to SOAP API, bdwreferencerequest_in. However my integration suite is failing at this POST step with unclear error message. Can someone please explain what should be the URL, required configurations and sample payload for this request.

https://api.sap.com/api/BDWREFERENCEREQUEST_IN/overview

#SAP BTP SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: Support for 16KB page compatibility in AppGyver, which Google is requiring
entry.content:
The Google Play Console has now required all Android apps to support 16KB pages by November 1, 2025, and has stated that apps will need to be recompiled to ensure continuous updates. Failure to meet this requirement may result in the app being suspended from the platform.

Since we use AppGyver (no-code) to develop our apps, we don't have direct access to the build settings. Therefore, it is essential that, at the time of creation, the app is generated in compliance with this technical requirement, that is, with support for 16KB pages.

In light of this, I am requesting guidance and support from SAP to ensure that, when editing or creating new apps in AppGyver, the generated build package complies with the new Google Play Console requirements.

Thank you in advance for your attention and I look forward to hearing from you with instructions on how to proceed in this case. If possible, please send me the links where I can ask for help, since the build generated in AppGyver is done using no-code, without the possibility of manual adjustments, and must already be compiled in the version requested by Google.

Project ID: P2006971219
Contact email: portfoliozx@gmail.com

Sincerely,
Vianeis Rodrigues Pereira.

entry.title: Power Designer - Reverse Engeneering Postgresql using script file
entry.content:
Hi,

Reverse Engeneering Postgresql using script file leads to the Tables and views defined in the pg_dump.sql file. But: All indexes and foreign key relationships are not in the PDM generated. 

Using the same script file and creating a Postgres database and do the reverse engeneering against this new DB will generate these important informations.

Have you experienced the same issue? is there a fix for that problem known?

Thanks

Ulrich
